title: Doubts ACCC can win TPG case
text:
Second, he was equally firm in declaring he will sell TPG’s mobile spectrum if the ban on the merger is affirmed by the court.

TPG paid a record $1.2 billion for the 700 MHz spectrum in April 2017. But without the spectrum TPG’s mobile ambitions are as dead as a dodo.

No rush

Chanticleer believes Teoh will not be rushing out to build a fourth mobile network if the merger is banned, mainly because of the evidence of former head of mobile networks at Telstra, Mike Wright.

Wright was presented by the ACCC as their star witness. When Michael Hodge, QC, who represented the ACCC, introduced Wright he described him in glowing terms.

Hodge said Wright “is, with all due respect your honour, vastly more experienced, we would say in understanding the details of rolling out and operating a mobile network in Australia”.

“And he has the added advantage, distinct from some of the other witnesses that will appear in front of your honour, which is that he is disinterested and objective. He has no dog in this fight.”

It is one of the peculiar aspects of this case that both the ACCC and Vodafone and TPG rely on Wright’s evidence to prosecute their arguments.

Advertisement

The ACCC says Wright’s expert evidence shows it is possible for TPG to build a fourth network. But TPG say Wright’s evidence shows such a network would not be commercially viable because it would be patchy, suffer congestion and need to be doubled in size compared to TPG’s original plan.

Vodafone relied on Wright’s evidence about its looming lack of competitiveness should the merger not go ahead. Essentially, Wright said without the merger Vodafone’s network would suffer congestion and have to raise prices to keep it functioning properly.

There was evidence Vodafone's excessive debt would prevent it from making the necessary capital investment in its network required to meet the explosion in data consumption on mobiles.

Middleton's poker face

Throughout the trial, Middleton was careful to play a straight bat in his interactions with barristers from the ACCC, Vodafone (Ruth Higgins, SC) and TPG (Peter Brereton, SC). He gave nothing away about which side he would ultimately support.

Also, he displayed a strong sense of scepticism about what people say in court when pursuing a mega-deal.

He said there was a “line of authority” in “corporate litigation where directors or businessmen get up and make self-serving statements, and there's a lot of authority that says the court should be very careful about accepting at face value – not because you disbelieve them or they're lying or whatever, but it's just an inclination of human nature”.

At another point Middleton said: “I sort of remind you of core promises and non-core promises and people changing their mind. And there’s ingenuity in explaining to the market why you have changed your mind. And maybe I am being too cynical, but anyhow.”

Chanticleer gets the sense the ACCC is now more confident than it was before the trial began that there is a “real chance” Teoh will build a fourth network if the ban on the merger is maintained. Vodafone and TPG seem equally confident of their positions.

Meanwhile, the two-year hiatus in the mobile market that has been gifted to the two dominant players, Telstra and Optus, will continue for another five months while Middleton writes his judgement.
description: A three-week court case challenging the ACCC ban on the $15 billion merger between Vodafone and TPG has left both sides confident of victory. But Chanticleer senses another ACCC loss.
